articles.headline: White House Pivots in Mideast Peace Bid
articles.snippet: President Obama is largely setting aside his demand for a full freeze on settlements in the West Bank.
articles.abstract: President Obama is largely setting aside his demand for a full freeze on settlements in the West Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS  President Obama, who has met immovable resistance from Israel over his demand for a full freeze on settlements in the West Bank, is largely setting that issue aside as a first step toward restarting Middle East peace talks.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: H.P.’s Bet in Buying E.D.S. Seems a Winner
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard’s move to acquire Electronic Data Systems and become a technology services company appears to have worked, but it has been hard on E.D.S.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard’s move to acquire Electronic Data Systems and become a technology services company appears to have worked, but it has been hard on E.D.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.  By many measures, it has been a tough year for employees of Electronic Data Systems.

articles.headline: Chase and Bank of America Revise Fee Policies
articles.snippet: Two banks are changing their debit card programs to end some charges that have enraged consumers.
articles.abstract: Two banks are changing their debit card programs to end some charges that have enraged consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, two of the nation’s biggest banks, announced plans on Tuesday to drastically overhaul their debit card programs by lowering or eliminating fees, changing the way they credit transactions and allowing customers to opt out of overdraft protection.

articles.headline: Emphasis on Growth Is Called Misguided
articles.snippet: A report says that human welfare should factor far more heavily when assessing how well the economy is performing.
articles.abstract: A report says that human welfare should factor far more heavily when assessing how well the economy is performing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the possible casualties of the Great Recession are the gauges that economists have traditionally relied upon to assess societal well-being. So many jobs have disappeared so quickly and so much life savings has been surrendered that some argue the economic indicators themselves have been exposed as inadequate.

articles.headline: Medical Malpractice System Breeds More Waste
articles.snippet: Researchers estimate that doctors’ fear of lawsuits leads to up to $60 billion a year worth of wasteful treatment.
articles.abstract: Researchers estimate that doctors’ fear of lawsuits leads to up to $60 billion a year worth of wasteful treatment.

articles.headline: With a Receptive White House, Labor Begins to Line Up Battles
articles.snippet: The Obama administration, though it says it supports free trade, has so far seemed aligned with labor’s trade agenda.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration, though it says it supports free trade, has so far seemed aligned with labor’s trade agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: When China’s president, Hu Jintao, attends the G-20 summit meeting this week in Pittsburgh, he will no doubt complain about the punitive tariffs that the Obama administration recently slapped on Chinese tires and steel.

articles.headline: U.S. Census Uses Telenovela to Reach Hispanics
articles.snippet: A character in a Spanish-language soap opera will work for the Census Bureau in a plot intended to encourage viewers to participate in the 2010 count.
articles.abstract: A character in a Spanish-language soap opera will work for the Census Bureau in a plot intended to encourage viewers to participate in the 2010 count.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  Perla Beltrán, a young woman from the wrong side of the tracks in New York, has suffered a great deal lately  her husband, a thief, has been murdered and she has been associating with lowlifes. But she thinks she has found a way out: as a recruiter for the United States Census Bureau.

articles.headline: Obama Considers Strategy Shift in Afghan War
articles.snippet: A plan advocated by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. would scale back American forces and focus more on Al Qaeda than on the Taliban, officials said.
articles.abstract: A plan advocated by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. would scale back American forces and focus more on Al Qaeda than on the Taliban, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama is exploring alternatives to a major troop increase in Afghanistan, including a plan advocated by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to scale back American forces and focus more on rooting out Al Qaeda there and in Pakistan, officials said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: Obama Makes Gains at U.N. on Iran and Proliferation
articles.snippet: President Obama, in his first visit to the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, made progress on two key issues crucial to his foreign policy.
articles.abstract: President Obama, in his first visit to the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, made progress on two key issues crucial to his foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS  President Obama, in his first visit to the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, made progress Wednesday on two key issues, wringing a concession from Russia to consider tough new sanctions against Iran and securing support from Moscow and Beijing for a Security Council resolution to curb nuclear weapons.

articles.headline: White House Pares Its Financial Reform Plan
articles.snippet: The administration dropped plans to require that banks offer simplified “plain vanilla” loans and credit cards.
articles.abstract: The administration dropped plans to require that banks offer simplified “plain vanilla” loans and credit cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a step toward overhauling the nation’s financial regulation, a senior Democrat on Wednesday announced a plan that preserved the core of the White House’s proposal for a new consumer financial protection agency, while jettisoning a smaller though symbolically significant provision that had posed political obstacles.
